Continue reading the main story

World

News, features and opinion curated for readers interested in Australia and the region.

News, features and opinion curated for readers interested in Australia and the region.

  • Latest
  • Search

  1. The Problem With Problem Sharks

    A marine biologist’s ideas for singling out sharks that attack humans have prompted objections from other shark scientists.

    By Jason Nark

    Jan. 1, 2021

  2. Australia Tweaks Anthem to Recognize Indigenous History

    The words “we are young and free” were changed to “we are one and free.” The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have lived on the continent for more than 60,000 years.

    By Jacey Fortin

    Dec. 31, 2020

  3. Times Insider

    What’s on the Horizon for the Climate Desk

    After a year when climate-related disasters seemed to become the norm, the team will be monitoring a 2021 that is pivotal for the world.

    By Mark Shimabukuro

    Dec. 30, 2020

  4. The World’s Dispatches

    In 2020, We Were There: The Year’s 13 Most Popular Dispatches

    Even challenged by extraordinary travel restrictions, our correspondents explored the world’s most compelling places, in 49 countries, although their journeys often became more local, and personal.

    By Bryant Rousseau

    阅读简体中文版閱讀繁體中文版

    Dec. 29, 2020

  5. Sailors Stranded for Months as China Refuses to Let Ships Unload Australian Coal

    China is vague about why vessels that carried Australian coal to its ports can’t unload their cargo. “We’re all depressed; our mental health is deteriorating,” one sailor said.

    By Yan Zhuang

    阅读简体中文版閱讀繁體中文版

    Dec. 26, 2020

  6. Four Charged Over Blaze That Devastated Australia’s Fraser Island

    The police said the men started an illegal campfire, but experts said the region would remain vulnerable to more fires as climate change worsens dry conditions.

    By Livia Albeck-Ripka

    Dec. 22, 2020

  7. Your Tuesday Briefing

    Britain’s sudden coronavirus Christmas isolation.

    By Natasha Frost

    Dec. 21, 2020

  8. ‘The Whole City Was Dark’: China Rations Electricity for Millions

    Warning of coal shortages, officials are trying to curb energy usage by telling residents not to use electric stoves and extinguishing lights on building facades and billboards.

    By Vivian Wang

    阅读简体中文版閱讀繁體中文版

    Dec. 21, 2020

  9. Trilobites

    More Mammals Are Hiding Their Secret Glow

    First it was platypuses. Now we may be dealing with glowing Tasmanian devils, echidnas and wombats.

    By Cara Giaimo

    Dec. 18, 2020

  10. ‘A Social Species’: How Kangaroos Communicate With People

    Researchers say that kangaroos are the first wild animals to exhibit interspecies communication that is more commonly seen in animals that have evolved alongside humans.

    By Yan Zhuang

    Dec. 18, 2020

  11. Letter 189

    International students in Australia prepare to spend the holidays away from family

    It’s been a rough year surviving the pandemic away from home.

    By Yan Zhuang

    Dec. 17, 2020

  12. ‘Nightmare’ Australia Housing Lockdown Called Breach of Human Rights

    An ombudsman’s report condemned a rushed lockdown of nine public housing towers in Melbourne that left thousands of residents without adequate food and medication and access to fresh air.

    By Livia Albeck-Ripka

    Dec. 17, 2020

  13. Your Thursday Briefing

    Cronyism and waste in Britain’s pandemic spending.

    By Natasha Frost

    Dec. 17, 2020

  14. Australian Open Is Postponed Because of the Coronavirus Pandemic

    With infections surging in other parts of the world, the first Grand Slam tennis event of 2021 has been delayed by three weeks, according to a schedule released by the men’s tour.

    By Matthew Futterman

    Dec. 16, 2020

    15. Advertisement

    Continue reading the main story

  15. Red Sox. White Sox. Blue Sox? Manny Is Still Manny.

    The Sydney Blue Sox were stunned that Manny Ramirez, 48, wanted to join the Australian Baseball League. They’re counting on the former superstar to raise baseball’s profile in the country.

    By Gary Phillips

    Dec. 16, 2020

  16. news analysis

    China Battles the World’s Biggest Coal Exporter, and Coal Is Losing

    China has officially blocked coal imports from Australia after months of vague restrictions. For Australia, the world’s largest coal exporter, the decision is a gut punch.

    By Damien Cave

    阅读简体中文版閱讀繁體中文版

    Dec. 16, 2020

  17. ‘Free Papua Movement’ Intensifies Amid Escalating Violence

    West Papua was annexed by Indonesia decades ago, leading to a prolonged conflict. A tribal chief who lives overseas recently declared himself president of the embattled territory.

    By Richard C. Paddock

    Dec. 12, 2020

  18. TimesVideo

    Australia Scraps Coronavirus Vaccine

    Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia on Friday canceled a large order of a developed coronavirus vaccine after not having the approval from the Therapeutic Goods Administration, the country’s drug regulator.

    By The Associated Press

    Dec. 11, 2020

  19. ¿En qué se parecen un príncipe y un obrero? Ambos pagaron miles de dólares por violar el confinamiento

    En todo el mundo, desobedecer las regulaciones del coronavirus puede tener consecuencias costosas.

    By Livia Albeck-Ripka

    Read in English

    Dec. 11, 2020

  20. Australia Scraps Covid-19 Vaccine That Produced H.I.V. False Positives

    Of the dozens of coronavirus vaccines being tested worldwide, the one under development at the University of Queensland was the first to be abandoned.

    By Mike Ives

    Dec. 11, 2020

Continue reading the main story
